verses.text: When Solomon had finished building the house of the Lord, the king’s house, and all that Solomon wanted to build,
verses.comment: ‘House of the Lord’ refers to the temple; ‘the king’s house’ is Solomon’s palace.

verses.text: the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, just as He had appeared to him at Gibeon.
verses.comment: First appearance was in Gibeon (ch. 3:5); this is the second.

verses.text: And the Lord said to him: “I have heard your prayer and your plea that you made before Me. I have consecrated this temple which you have built, to put My name there forever; My eyes and My heart will always be there.
verses.comment: ‘Put My name there’ means God’s presence and ownership.

verses.text: If you walk before Me as your father David walked, with integrity and uprightness, doing all I have commanded you and keeping My statutes and ordinances,
verses.comment: Integrity and uprightness echo the covenant standards set with David.

verses.text: then I will establish the throne of your kingdom over Israel forever, as I promised your father David, saying, ‘You will never lack a man on the throne of Israel.’
verses.comment: God’s covenant with David is reemphasized.

verses.text: But if you or your sons turn away from following Me, and do not keep My commands and My statutes which I have set before you, but go and serve other gods and worship them,
verses.comment: The condition of obedience for the continuation of Solomon’s dynasty.

verses.text: then I will cut off Israel from the land that I have given them; and the temple that I have consecrated for My name I will cast out of My sight, and Israel will become a proverb and a byword among all peoples.
verses.comment: Warning of exile and disgrace for national unfaithfulness.

verses.text: This temple will become a heap of ruins. Everyone who passes by it will be astonished and will hiss; and they will say, ‘Why has the Lord done this to this land and to this temple?’
verses.comment: The ‘hiss’ refers to an expression of scorn or amazement.

verses.text: And they will answer, ‘Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who brought their ancestors out of the land of Egypt, and embraced other gods and worshiped them and served them; that is why the Lord has brought all this evil upon them.’”
verses.comment: Highlights the link between covenant unfaithfulness and judgment.

verses.text: At the end of twenty years, during which Solomon had built the two houses, the house of the Lord and the king’s house,
verses.comment: Building the temple took 7 years; the palace 13 years (totals 20, ch. 6:38, 7:1).

verses.text: King Solomon gave twenty cities in the land of Galilee to Hiram king of Tyre, because Hiram had supplied Solomon with cedar and cypress timber and with gold, according to all he desired.
verses.comment: Hiram had provided materials for the temple and palace.

verses.text: So Hiram came out from Tyre to see the cities that Solomon had given him, but they did not please him.
verses.comment: No major difference from original; Tyre is a coastal city north of Israel.

verses.text: He said, “What kind of cities are these which you have given me, my brother?” So he called them the land of Cabul, as they are called to this day.
verses.comment: 'Cabul' means 'good for nothing' or 'worthless.'

verses.text: And Hiram had sent the king one hundred and twenty talents of gold.
verses.comment: A talent is about 75 pounds (34 kg).

verses.text: This is the account of the forced labor that King Solomon imposed for building the house of the Lord, his own house, Millo, the wall of Jerusalem, Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
verses.comment: ‘Millo’ refers to a fortification or supporting structure in Jerusalem.

verses.text: Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up and captured Gezer, burned it with fire, killed the Canaanites who lived in the city, and given it as a dowry to his daughter, Solomon’s wife.
verses.comment: Gezer was a Canaanite city given as part of Pharaoh’s daughter’s marriage to Solomon.

verses.text: So Solomon rebuilt Gezer, Lower Beth-horon,
verses.comment: Lower Beth-horon was a fortified town northwest of Jerusalem.

verses.text: Baalath and Tamar in the wilderness, in the land of Judah,
verses.comment: Baalath and Tamar are southern and northern fortresses built by Solomon.

verses.text: and all the storage cities that Solomon had, the cities for his chariots, the cities for his horsemen, and all that Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and throughout all the land of his dominion.
verses.comment: Shows the extent of Solomon’s building projects.

verses.text: All the people who were left of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, who were not of the people of Israel—
verses.comment: Lists the remaining Canaanite nations not driven out.

verses.text: their descendants who were left after them in the land, whom the Israelites were unable to completely destroy—Solomon conscripted them for forced labor, as they are to this day.
verses.comment: Forced labor applied to non-Israelites, a common ancient practice.

verses.text: But Solomon did not make slaves of the Israelites; instead, they were men of war, his servants, officers, captains, commanders of his chariots, and his horsemen.
verses.comment: Israelites served in official and military roles, not as forced labor.

verses.text: These were the chief officers who were over Solomon’s work: five hundred and fifty, who had charge of the people who did the work.
verses.comment: Management structure for Solomon’s building and labor force.

verses.text: But Pharaoh’s daughter went up from the city of David to her own house, which Solomon had built for her. Then he built the Millo.
verses.comment: Pharaoh’s daughter had her own palace; Millo is a fortification or fill.

verses.text: Three times a year Solomon offered burnt offerings and peace offerings on the altar which he had built for the Lord, burning incense with them on the altar before the Lord. So he finished the temple.
verses.comment: Three annual festivals: Passover, Pentecost, Tabernacles (see Lev. 23).

verses.text: King Solomon built a fleet of ships at Ezion-geber, which is near Eloth on the shore of the Red Sea, in the land of Edom.
verses.comment: Ezion-geber and Eloth are port cities; Red Sea here is also ‘Sea of Reeds.’

verses.text: And Hiram sent his servants, seamen who were familiar with the sea, with Solomon’s servants to the fleet.
verses.comment: Hiram’s men had trading and navigation experience.

verses.text: They went to Ophir and brought back from there gold, four hundred and twenty talents, and delivered it to King Solomon.
verses.comment: Ophir’s location is unknown, often suggested to be in Arabia or Africa. 420 talents ≈ 31,500 lb or ≈ 14,300 kg.
